instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Throttling, liquid damage
threads.message: Hi everyone. I have this board that came in with liquid damage. Damage was around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> area and <CHIP>U9500</CHIP>. I replaced ISL, <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and resistors in that area as well as <CHIP>U9500</CHIP> and components in that area. Machine turns on but is very slow to boot into OS and fans throttle high shortly after it is turned on though it doesn't seem to be overheating. When it does boot into OS everything is very slow. It does this on battery and/or on charger & trackpad/KB connected or disconnected. Thank you, have a good day.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Throttling, liquid damage
threads.message: Run ASD EFI version to check for sensor errors. Probably <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> corroded trace to it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Throttling, liquid damage
threads.message: Hey Duke. Ran ASD EFI. Got SMC IO failed error. (TC0D, TC0P, TP0P, TH1H, TH2H, TM0P) The area above the KB and TP connectors is warmer than the CPU GPU area. Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Throttling, liquid damage
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Throttling, liquid damage
threads.message:
Hi. I got a few. I just reposted. Thanks.


* Is it safe to assume that with the multiple errors that the SMC needs to be replaced? But like I said, it does get warm above the KB/TP area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Throttling, liquid damage
threads.message: Find what is getting hot, something is messing with the SMBUS for the thermal sensors. SMC is probably fine, it is something that is on the SMBUS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Throttling, liquid damage
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Throttling, liquid damage
threads.message:
Unfortunately I could not locate the problem. I have been all over SMBUS line. The only thing that I have right now is that pin 1 of <CHIP>U5570</CHIP> does not stay steady 3.3 v. It jumps very vigorously between 3.33V and 3.26V. I have compared to another working board, and this does not occur. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is a steady 3.3V on other test points I have tried. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is steady on pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R5570</RESISTOR>. When I remove <CHIP>U5570</CHIP> voltage on pin 1 is steady.Thank you. Have a good one.

*Replaced SMC just in case. Same result like you said.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Throttling, liquid damage
threads.message: If the KB and TP connector area is getting that hot you must be able to find which component it is. It is probably causing all the issues.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Throttling, liquid damage
threads.message: Yea... Though it seems warm in that general area (underside of SMC), there is not one thing that is actually hot. Ive been over everything. Alcohol will evaporate quicker on that area, but its broad and nothing in particular is "hot". Maybe this is just normal behavior and I was going in the wrong direction thinking otherwise. Sorry.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Throttling, liquid damage
threads.message:
Diode mode on <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_B_S0_SDA</SIGNAL> and SCL. Check corrosion around <CHIP>U5570</CHIP>, <CHIP>U5520</CHIP>. Check <RESISTOR>R5260</RESISTOR>/61.
Replaced <CHIP>U5570</CHIP> with another?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Throttling, liquid damage
threads.message: Hi. Diode mode on pins 9 and 10 of <CHIP>U5570</CHIP> is .486. Have already replaced <CHIP>U5570</CHIP>, <CHIP>U5520</CHIP> as well as <RESISTOR>R5260</RESISTOR>/61. Thanks. Have a good one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Throttling, liquid damage
threads.message: Short the data lines together and see if you get the same errors or if there are more.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Throttling, liquid damage
threads.message: data lines as in pins 2,3,4,5. Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Throttling, liquid damage
threads.message: Data lines going to <RESISTOR>R5260</RESISTOR>/61. It is just to make sure we're dealing with the correct SMBUS. Shorting out those data lines will not cause more errors if they already have an issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Throttling, liquid damage
threads.message:
Before I had a chance to shorting out lines the board stopped booting with trackpad plugged in. In the end I ended up replacing <CHIP>U5805</CHIP> and <DIODE>D5802</DIODE>. Board no longer throttles. However, I now have a very quiet high pitch squeal coming from somewhere, almost like a feed back sound. Seem to be around the center of the board but Im not certain. Squeal seems to change pitch with fans motion. Any thoughts?
Thanks have a good day.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Throttling, liquid damage
threads.message: I can not diagnose a noise over the internet....disconnect fans and see if it is gone.
